--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
>=
 Now I don't necessarily agree that checking an exception message is 
> /go=
od design/. I also don't necessarily agree that having a negative 
> value =
for 'score' is cause for an exception--it depends where the
system 
> bound=
aries are.

In this case "points" was the count of JUnit or Agitator assert=
ions --
negative values were non-sensical.

And I'm not sure checking the e=
xception message in my test is a
question of design at all, but out of curi=
ousity, how do you TDD
throwing an exception?

> Finally, I should mention =
that this is not the kind of design problem I 
> have in mind when I made m=
y admittedly baseless claim. Since it was 
> baseless, I should revise my c=
laim. Here it is:
> 
>      When I write JUnit tests, I am forced to deal w=
ith dependency
>      problems in my code. I don't yet have any evidence th=
at Agitator
>      would help me with that. I am concerned that since Agita=
tor helps
>      me /not/ write JUnit tests, it might also help me /not/ fe=
el the
>      pain of those kinds of dependency problems.
> 

I think it is=
 a reasonable concern but not something to fear in
practice. I don't think =
I've ever worked with a customer where I
haven't pointed to the screen and =
said something about dependency
injection.

fwiw about the only JUnit tests=
 that I haven't written becuase of
Agitator are the ones I would have writt=
en to fix the bugs that would
have otherwise have been reported.  :)

Jtf
